item.title: Animations
item.content:encoded:
Provided below are links to some animations that will be used in lecture during the course of the semester. Please feel free to review and study these animations and discussions at any time during the semester.
2D Moving Reference Frame Example Angular Momentum Examples Ball Bounce Bike Jump Braking reactions Center of percussion Chasles' Theorem Geneva mechanism Gyro joint Impact problems Instant centers MEMS gyroscope Merry-go-round and the Coriolis component of acceleration Rolling without slipping Rotating imbalance Tire instant center Two-force members and dynamics Vibes examples

item.title: Visualizing Mechanics
item.content:encoded: The Visualizing Mechanics initiative seeks to bring experiments and classroom demonstrations to you.  Please take some time to review these videos and see how what you are learning in the classroom applies to these situations.   Highlight Videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ED3LXV6JWCA https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kfECWaKQXSg Other Videos: Base-Excited Vibrations Centers of Mass Coefficient of Friction Conservation of Linear Momentum in a Ball Launcher Conservation of Linear Momentum in Inelastic Collisions Deflection in I-Beams Experimental Determination of Radius of Gyration Impending Motion of a Spool Rolling Without Slip Instantaneous Centers of Rotation of a Simple Mechanism Investigating Inertia Newton's Second Law - The Water Bucket Path Tracing on an Object Rolling Without Slip Rope-Pulley Kinematics Rotating Reference Frames - A Merry-Go-Round The Ballistic Pendulum The Dynamics Behind Impact Forces The Effect of Friction on a Falling Rigid Body The Natural Frequency of a Spring-Mass System The Vibration of Chladni Plates The Vibration of Strings The Work-Energy Equation - A Simple Rollercoaster Hill

item.title: Lecture Example Videos
item.content:encoded: Below you will find videos of each of the examples included in the course lecturebook.  Please review them as you work to complete your homework and prepare for course examinations.  As always, if you have any additional questions, do not hesitate to ask! Chapter 0: Example 0.A.1 Example 0.A.2 Example 0.A.3 Example 0.B.1 Example 0.B.2 Example 0.B.3 Example 0.C.1 Example 0.C.2 Example 0.C.3 Example 0.C.4 Chapter 1: Example 1.A.1 Example 1.A.2 Example 1.A.3 Example 1.A.4 Example 1.B.1 Example 1.B.2 Example 1.C.1 Example 1.C.2 Example 1.C.3 Example 1.C.4 Example 1.D.1 Example 1.D.2 Example 1.D.3 Example 1.D.4 Example 1.D.5 Example 1.D.6 Chapter 2: Example 2.A.1 Example 2.A.2 Example 2.A.3 Example 2.A.4 Example 2.A.5 Example 2.A.6 Example 2.A.7 Example 2.A.8 Example 2.A.9 Example 2.A.10 Example 2.B.1 Example 2.B.2 Example 2.B.3 Example 2.B.4 Example 2.B.5 Example 2.B.6 Example 2.B.7 Example 2.B.8 Example 2.C.1 Example 2.C.2 Chapter 3: Example 3.A.1 Example 3.A.2 Example 3.A.3 Example 3.A.4 Example 3.A.5 Example 3.A.6 Example 3.A.7 Example 3.B.1 Example 3.B.2 Example 3.B.3 Example 3.B.4 Example 3.B.5 Example 3.B.6 Example 3.B.7 Example 3.B.8 Example 3.B.9 Example 3.B.10 Example 3.B.11 Example 3.B.11 - item.title: Welcome!
item.content:encoded: Welcome to the ME 274: Basic Mechanics II Course Blog for the Spring 2015 semester. This Blog will serve as the electronic portal for all course materials. Please feel free to browse and do not hesitate to contact your instructor if you have any questions.

item.title: Course Information
Homework 1.A
item.content:encoded: Please use this post to discuss Homework 1.A

item.title: Homework 1.B
item.content:encoded: Please use this post to discuss Homework 1.B

item.title: Homework 1.C

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Is there a change in Theta for the first part of the question or is in unnecessary for solving Part 1?
I believe that theta is constant, therefore theta dot and theta double dot will just be zero.

We can't make the assumption that theta is equal to 0. There is just not enough information. Otherwise, the rollercoaster would be stationary.
With the information given in the problem, I don't think it's possible to figure out the velocity in terms of time.

If you look at the equation, you can find the position of the car at theta = pi/10, which, judging from the diagram and the second part of the equation is the distance from the car to the center of curvature. From there, you can solve it in terms of path kinematics.

I agree with you. The rollercoaster is not stationary, and it will be physically impossible if the theta is pi/10 and the rollercoaster is stationary at the same time. I would believe there's lack of information.

Hi All-
There is some missing information in problem H.1.C, Part I.
Please assume that theta_dot = 2*t^2 rad/s. Then, evaluate the velocity and acceleration of the car at t = 2 seconds in addition to theta = pi/10.
Thanks, DC
For part 2, Can you calculate the radius without knowing the angle?
Never mind, darr's post answered my question.

item.title: Homework 1.F
Homework 1.G
Homework 1.H
Homework 1.I
Homework 1.J
Homework 2.A

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I am struggling to find angular speed and velocity. Does anyone have a hint to get me started? Thanks!

Clarify... Do you mean you are having troubles finding the angular velocity needed to find the velocity of point B in this problem?
If so, then it would be easier to start working on this problem with the earlier version of the equation instead of jumping straight to the final equation the book gives us.. (for example, instead of V(b/a) = omega x r(b/a), use V(b/a) = Vb - Va = r(dot) E(hat)r + r Theta(dot) E(hat)theta.) We know that r(dot) is zero since the length of the bar does not change. Therefore we only need to find Theta(dot). This can be done by setting up a relation equation using the sine rules, deriving, and solving for Theta(dot). (important to note that the speed of point A is constant and is in a different coordinate system, so you will need to navigate different coordinate systems in this problem.)

item.title: Homework 2.B
Homework 2.C
Homework 2.D

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Is w positive or negative? the direction indicates w is negative but the parameter given is positive.
In my experience, sign is just convention, so if you designate the positive direction in your answer you can't go wrong.
Should we assume that the given angular acceleration is rotating counterclockwise? It is not drawn on the diagram like velocity is.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: How do we find omega? So far I have tried using the relative velocity equation v_a/o. Should I be using a different reference point like d instead of o? I'm missing something here.

b = 10 in is given in the problem, but it is not on the diagram. I believe it is the length of OB. If this is true than you can use rotating reference frame for AO and rigid body for AB and then equate your i and j components.
Sorry I thought this was for c. Disregard that comment.
v_a/d will be used to find the derivative of l, I don't think there is enough information to use it to find omega

item.title: Homework 3.E
Homework 3.F

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This is a test!
test

item.title: Homework 3.G
Homework 3.H

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Because the acceleration of the entire figure in the positive X direction is zero, does this mean the v(dot) is also zero?
Is the j axis considered fixed? I'm confused whether it can still be considered fixed since the whole crane is moving right but not accelerating.

item.title: Homework 3.I
Homework 3.J
Homework 4.A

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm a bit confused on the wording of the problem. When it mentions a 'horizontal plane,' does that mean that the ball is essentially rolling on a table, and there's no gravitational force to be considered?

Replying to darr: Yes, as it says its a horizontal plane, we would be considering only the plane as seen from above, so no gravitational forces would be considered. The ball here is rolling on the table and we are simply considering its motion on the table.

item.title: Homework 4.B
Homework 4.C

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I am trying to solve this problem under oplar coordinates system, but I am not sure if I need to calculate for r dot or we just simply consider it as zero?

It can be considered as zero. If you watch the Lecture Example video 4A.13, it is a similar problem that explains the process. Make sure when you plug in numbers you convert the gravity constant to be in terms of inches, not feet, or else you'll get a coefficient >1
Thank you! I really appreciate your help!

Remember that the coefficient of static friction isn't necessarily between 0 and 1, it is only a measure of how effectively the normal force translates into friction. For instance, the coefficient of static friction for rubber is 1.16 (http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/friction-coefficients-d_778.html).
Thank you for clearing that darr, I wasn't aware of that, however, I did get a coefficient of friction to be between 0 and 1. Just confirming. Thanks anyway.
(test comment, ignore this)

item.title: Homework 4.D

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: If we are considering the gravitational force, then we need angle theta to solve the problem.....However the theta is not given, does anyone know how to get theta?

I was having the same issue as you. I then looked at the 4.A.10 lecture example video which is essentially the exact same problem. In the video, gravity wasn't even considered. Therefore, I would go ahead and do the problem neglecting gravity. It may not be the correct way to do the problem, but it seems to be what they want.

In that example the arm is in the horizontal plane. (That is why you do not consider gravity(it's going into the page)) This problem does not say the arm is in the horizontal plane, so I don't think you can neglect the gravity
I have an answer in terms of theta and explained what theta would make the box act on a or b.
I am also going to just leave the answers in terms of theta.

Oh my god, guys guys guys, if you read the question once again, it says that the arm rotates about a vertical axis. This means that this is a horizontal plane, and hence you don't need to consider gravity. So you don't need to know theta in this question at all. Hope this clears all your doubts.
I emailed Professor Cappelleri and he said that we do not need to know theta to solve the problem. I still get answers that involve theta, but just passing along the info he gave me.

You do not need theta to solve the problem. Remember it states the arm is rotating about a VERTICAL axis. So it is lying in a horizontal plane with an axis standing up vertically that it rotates around.

item.title: Homework 4.E
Homework 4.F

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: So, I was trying to solve for the second derivative of 2SB+sqrt(h^2+SA^2) + c = L but after I got the first derivative which is 2SB'+SA*SA'/sqrt(h^2+SA^2) I don't know how to derive the second derivative. How do I compute for SA*SA'/sqrt(h^2+SA^2)?
https://www.math.ucdavis.edu/~kouba/CalcOneDIRECTORY/quotientruledirectory/QuotientRule.html

item.title: Homework 4.G

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Not sure if I am overthinking this one or not but I cant figure out how to relate the speeds of A and B. Should I use the rope length equation? it seems like it would be complicated that way with all the pulleys connected to B. Or is there a way to show that they are directly proportional?
I believe the rope length equation and the Work/energy equation are sufficient to find the speeds of A and B.
Are you guys getting the speed of A to be like 3 times bigger than the speed of B?
I got that A is 1.5x bigger than B @lawrenc

item.title: Homework 4.H

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I have more variables than equations for this problem. Was anybody able to solve it?

Try working the problem with your system defined as mass A, mass B, and the rod. You should then get only one work producing force (that is, a force that points in the direction of motion). From there, use the equation discussed in class last Friday. Hope this helps.

item.title: Homework 4.I

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Getting a K value of -946854 - which I'm feeling as wrong:
Final M/E equation is: P*(1.562 - 1.00319) = (1/2)*k*delta^2 + Pgrav
The work done by the nonconservative P force isn't nearly enough to cover the Pgrav, let alone the Pgrav and Pspring.
What source of work am I missing / have I done incorrectly?

I tried solving and ran into the same issue. The only thing I can think of is that we should not account for gravity. I'm going to solve it as if the diagram is laying on the ground instead of standing up. It may not say that in the problem, but at least it will give a realistic answer.

It seems the problem cannot be solved if gravity is included, as there is no possible way a 50N force would be able to realistically lift a 28kg upward, since the gravitational force from the mass would be 274.68N.
Same here. I get negative for k if I include the gravity.

I put an assumption that the figure was in the vertical plane; I think that it is typical to assume vertical plane if the plane is not specified. I also got a similar negative k; I believe this means that the box would never touch the spring.

item.title: Homework 4.J
Homework 4.K

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Is 20lb a unit of pound-mass or pound-force in this case?

I would assume it's pound-force, since we know that P is a force, not a mass, and in the graph, P is labeled in "lb" in the same format as the 20lb block. I think "lb" will typically indicate a force, unless it specifies "lb-mass"

I think you would need to assume pound-mass. If you assume pound-force then you would need to divide by the acceleration to find the mass for either the impulse-momentum or the work-energy equations. That would make the mass kind of small since the acceleration of gravity for English units is 32.174 lb-f for one lb-m
Assume it's giving pounds force - convert to pounds mass for use - otherwise you'll get a negative v2 - which is definitely wrong

item.title: Homework 4.L

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: do we assume that they travels on a smooth surface?
Unless it is specified that the surface is rough, I think that is a safe assumption to make!
I assumed that it was smooth, but make sure to state your assumptions.

item.title: Homework 4.M

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: After solving for t critical using v2 = 0, I found that it is larger than deltaT. Does this mean that you can just take the integral for the work done by the friction from 0 to deltaT?

T critical denotes the time that the box slows to a halt, and begins to move in the opposite direction. If deltaT is less than that value, this means that the box is always moving in the same direction. If the work done depends on the direction the box is moving, you can indeed take the integral from 0 to deltaT instead of working out a piecewise function.

item.title: Homework 4.N

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: When solving for part a, what is everyone using for work done on particle B? I originally solved assuming work is zero, but I don't know if the normal force of the block would account for any work done.

When solving part a, you should draw a free body diagram that includes both block A and particle B. This means that there is no work done on particle B, nor particle A. Therefore, the work done due to non conservative forces is zero.

To be more general, the work term you're referring to is probably the non-conservative work term in the work/energy equation. In this case, if at all times every non-conservative force (i.e. forces not due to gravity, or springs) are acting at a 90 degree angle to the direction of motion, the work term will be zero since the work done is F dot dr(tangent). I hope this answers your question.

item.title: Homework 4.O
Homework 4.P

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Since the Triangular block A, will have the normal force acting on it, we can't use the central impact equations, except for the equation for restitution? How do we account for the impulsive force of the Normal force on A?
think slider as a ball only acting on x direction.
I just converted the velocity of A for the t and n directions. Then I used the momentum equation for A and B system. I think this is how you go about it, but I may be incorrect.

item.title: Homework 4.Q

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Can we assume a horizontal plane?

item.title: Homework 4.R
Homework 4.S

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I don't understand how the spring can be compressed in state 1. It's in a horizontal plane, so weight of P isn't holding it down. The rotation will cause a normal force in etheta direction, but there's no friction, so the only force in the er direction is the spring. If it is compressed, it should be pushing the mass away from O, but we're given that Rdot=0

Note that Rdot=0 at instant 1. Think of the particle P as oscillating; at the moment of maximum compression, its speed with respect to point O is zero. You're right that the spring is pushing the mass away from O, because Rdoubledot is nonzero (so at any moment after the first moment, Rdot will be nonzero). Does this explain things?

I'm confused on how to solve for the rdot at position 2. Can I use work energy to calculate the final velocity? I thought I could but I keep getting that there are no external forces so nothing changes from beginning to end.

item.title: Homework 4.T
Homework 5.A
Homework 5.B

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: So the moment about G is 0, since all the forces run through G. So in order to find angular accel, I tried to take the moment about A. But none of the dimensions are given. So how can I solve this?
figured it out. I = (1/12)mL^2 duh
@Colton There is a reaction force at A in both the x and y direction. The reaction force in the x direction will not go through the center of gravity.

item.title: Homework 5.C

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm trying to determine the moment of inertia, but the tables only account for uniform objects. Are there another set of equations I ought to be using?
You need to use the "parallel axis theorem" to get the moment of inertia for an arbitrary point. And that parallel axis theorem is on pg 305.

item.title: Homework 5.D

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Do the coefficients of friction apply to the surfaces between the pallet and disk AND the pallet and small circles underneath, or just the pallet and the disk?

item.title: Homework 5.E
Homework 5.F

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Do we need the dimensions for the bar to solve for I?
Could someone give some hints to get started on this problem?
You must set up a new reference frame in order to solve this problem.

item.title: Homework 5.G

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: do we assume that the cart (rectangular part) as homogeneous?
You should not need to make that assumption because the cart itself has no angular velocity.

I was trying to get the angular velocity equating the external work done on the wheel and the initial KE of the wheel, however, there are two unknowns, one is angular velocity and the other one is the external work. how do we find the value for "w" for wheels
I may be wrong but I don't think there should be any work done on the wheel
Also was the final compression fairly small?
I thought "w" is just v/R, since v = wR.

Yes, I think the angular velocity is just the velocity divided by the radius since the problem mentions no slipping bellow both the wheels. (there are 4) Also the question according to me would be solved in different components where there wouldn't be an angular velocity for the block.

Is it OK to assume that the velocity associated with the center of mass of both wheels is equivalent to the velocity of the block? I'm pretty sure this is the only way to cut it done to one variable and solve the problem.

item.title: Homework 5.H
Homework 5.I

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Will the answer for part a and part b be the same? Cause the disk is not rotating and it only has the 1/2mv^2 component at the center of mass. And isn't the disk considered as a point of particle with equal mass as the disk is not rotating?

Make sure that your whole T2 equation references one point. In this case you want to use O because it is a fixed point. Omega will be equal to the omega of the bar. Make sure that you use the formula Ia=Ig+Mdag^2 to find the moment of inertia of the bar disk and point.
See example 5.B.7
I think I was I incorrect omega of the disk is zero so the answers will be the same for a and b

The omega of the disk and the bar will be the same. Remember the disk is welded to the bar and will rotate about point O with the same omega as the bar. It does not have to be pinned to have a rotation.
the answers to each part should be different as the disk now a particle and won't have its own I about it
I really appreciate for all the comments and your helps!

I know how to do this problem now, but I am still confused of concepts for rotational kinetic energy. What if the problem states that the disk was rotating, what will be kinetic energy for the disk? will it have both rotational kinetic energy about point O and the rotational energy about its center as well? What is the exact definition for the kinetic energy including the rotational portion?

The Kinetic energy is in the case of the beam just the angular kinetic energy and for the wheel in the end it is the sum of both the translational and rotational kinetic energies. Watching lecture example 5.B.7 would be helpful.

item.title: Homework 5.J

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm stuck on the work done by nonconservitive forces. How is Mo used to find U? Also by finding omega oa and omega ab i still have 2unknowns. (One omega and Vb) any suggestions?

For the omegas, use instant center analysis on element AB given the constraints in the problem. From there, you should be able to derive a simple expression relating the velocity of B to the velocity of A. For the work done by Mo, we haven't done anything like this in class, nor are there any lecture examples I can find with an applied moment, so I treated it as a point force applied at A (Mo * L)
I think you should be able to just use the moment over the distance through which the arm swings.

My approach of solving this has been a little different and I might be wrong, but I have just found out the non conservative work by using Fdr which would be force dotted with the vector distance final minus the vector distance initial. So basically that is the non conserved work till the bar reaches its vertical.
And then after using it as a force you can take help from example 5.B.5

item.title: Homework 5.K

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: friction coefficient is not given. how can we find the friction force??
You don't need the coefficient of friction. Try solving using AIM around the contact point of the disk and the incline.
I thought we couldn't use the point of contact because it's not a fixed point. It's momentarily stationary since there's no slip, but it's still free to move
What is a0 when using the particle angular momentum equation? I have 5 equations and 5 unknowns (2 AIM, 2 W/E, and a kinematics equation)?
I think you should express your a0 as dv/dt. That is (v2-v1)/dt.

the no slip condition simply tells us that the angular velocity is nothing but the velocity divided by the radius , thus creating one less variable in the kinetic energy equations. You can cross check your answer using equations of motion....

huang, there are only 3 equations, because we're not using AIM,
yu, we're trying to find v2, so we need a number for a0.

item.title: Homework 5.L

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: My intuition tells me that concentrating some mass in the mass center (the bullet becoming part of the rod) won't affect the moment of inertia, both by the parallel axis theorem, and by the small relative mass. Am I off? I feel like my explanation is missing something.

Even though very slightly because of the 20g mass, it will , look at example 5.C.5, the difference is negligible because its the product of the mass of bullet and distance from top and they're both extremely small but I would recommend adding that to your calculation.
Is it possible to solve this by using LIM? Then using v=rw to find the velocity. Or can you not assume that v=rw in this case?

item.title: Homework 5.M

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: For this problem, is there a force acting on the top of the bar where the particle strikes the ball? If there is a force, how do we go about integrating that portion of the equation if there is not a given delta time.
You need to use LIM AIM and one more relationship to relate v and omega, but I am stuck on that I am stuck on because there are no pinned points
The professor said to use 5.C.5 and 5.C.7 to help with the problem

Ok, So yes, you have to use LIM in x direction and AIM in positive k direction to start with this problem. After that calculate the velocity of the point of impact using the center velocity in i and j direction (you will get an answer in the i direction) then you will get the same number of equations as unknowns, keep back substituting. You don't need the value of Fdt, just substitute expressions. In your LIM remember that your RHS has a combined mass velocity.

item.title: Homework 6.J
Homework 6.K

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: For both homework problems we have to find an EOM for the system, but the systems have multiple parts moving differently, so wouldn't each part have its own EOM? Am I missing a concept here?
You write a free body diagram for each body, but the EOM is for the system as a whole (think about a mass attached to a pulley. Two FBDs, one EOM).
For this problem, you will have total 3 FBDs that reduce to 1 EOM. To do this, try to solve for the equation of block C by using the equations of disk A and B.

So I think i figured out the solution. As yu209 states, you will have to write down the equations for all the three FBDs. And then solve for the equation of block C. And then even if you assume that each object has its own EOM, in the end you will have to assume that they all move by the same distance as they are all in no slip contact with each other. Thus reducing them to be a single EOM. A pretty simple one actually.
For the EOM of the system, do we need to draw a FDB for the whole system then do the EOM?
